articles.headline: Fight Over Retirement in France Is a Question of Identity
articles.snippet: Resistance to the government’s plan to push back the retirement age is not just about working longer. It springs from a deep sense of what defines France as a nation.
articles.abstract: Resistance to the government’s plan to push back the retirement age is not just about working longer. It springs from a deep sense of what defines France as a nation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Monday is line dancing; Tuesday scrapbooking with friends; Wednesday caring for her two grandchildren.

articles.headline: WeWork, Reeling From Cash Crunch, Tries to Shore Up Financial Footing
articles.snippet: The co-working giant is close to an agreement with SoftBank and others for new money and to restructure its debt.
articles.abstract: The co-working giant is close to an agreement with SoftBank and others for new money and to restructure its debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: WeWork, the troubled office space company built by the entrepreneur Adam Neumann that has struggled to right itself in recent years, is in talks with investors to restructure its outstanding debt of more than $3 billion and raise more cash.
articles.byline: By Maureen Farrell, Benjamin Mullin and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Walgreens Faces Blowback for Not Offering Abortion Pill in 21 States
articles.snippet: The chain’s situation shows the complicated legal and reputational landscape that it and its competitors must navigate in the post-Roe era.
articles.abstract: The chain’s situation shows the complicated legal and reputational landscape that it and its competitors must navigate in the post-Roe era.
articles.lead_paragraph: Walgreens landed at the center of a consumer and political firestorm in recent days, after saying it would not dispense an abortion pill in 21 states where Republican attorneys general have threatened legal action against pharmacies that try to distribute the medication.
articles.byline: By Pam Belluck and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: The Chatbots Are Here, and the Internet Industry Is in a Tizzy
articles.snippet: The new technology could upend many online businesses. But for companies that figure out how to work with it, A.I. could be a boon.
articles.abstract: The new technology could upend many online businesses. But for companies that figure out how to work with it, A.I. could be a boon.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Aaron Levie, the chief executive of Box, tried a new A.I. chatbot called ChatGPT in early December, it didn’t take him long to declare, “We need people on this!”
articles.byline: By Tripp Mickle, Cade Metz and Nico Grant

articles.headline: More Black Women Run for Office, but Prospects Fade the Higher They Go
articles.snippet: A Black woman has never been a governor, and only two have been senators. Despite progress at lower levels of government, and one boundary-breaking vice president, familiar barriers are slow to fall.
articles.abstract: A Black woman has never been a governor, and only two have been senators. Despite progress at lower levels of government, and one boundary-breaking vice president, familiar barriers are slow to fall.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Representative Barbara Lee hits the campaign trail for a Senate seat in California, significant hurdles await her. The race is expected to be one of the most competitive, and expensive, in the country. Even more daunting, she will face one of the strongest glass ceilings in American politics.

articles.headline: The Perils of Working on a C.E.O.’s Pet Project
articles.snippet: Big tech companies have long been willing to fund efforts with no obvious payoff. But those groups have been hit hard in recent layoffs.
articles.abstract: Big tech companies have long been willing to fund efforts with no obvious payoff. But those groups have been hit hard in recent layoffs.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — For years, working on a project that didn’t make a lot of sense to outsiders but was championed by the boss was a badge of honor for employees at some of the tech industry’s biggest companies. Google tried to create augmented reality glasses. Amazon developed its own high-end smartphone. Facebook changed its name to Meta and jumped headlong into the virtual world of the metaverse.
articles.byline: By Karen Weise, Nico Grant and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Adidas Is Wondering What to Do With $1.3 Billion in Yeezy Sneakers
articles.snippet: After severing business ties with the rapper Ye, Adidas said it would cut its dividend and declared 2023 a “transition year.”
articles.abstract: After severing business ties with the rapper Ye, Adidas said it would cut its dividend and declared 2023 a “transition year.”
articles.lead_paragraph: The new chief executive of Adidas has $1.3 billion in Yeezy sneakers he doesn’t know what to do with.
